title: London Telegraph's owners in £500m cash call for ailing empire
text:
London | The billionaire Barclay brothers, who own The Ritz hotel in London and Britain’s Telegraph newspaper, are close to pumping half a billion pounds into their ailing empire even as they review the assets for possible sale.

David and Frederick Barclay have poured in £325 million ($610 million) in the past 18 months, according to analysis of public filings, and they face a new cash call at Shop Direct that would take the total to £500 million.

The billionaire twins, who turned 85 on Sunday, have now authorised a full review of their businesses. They have started a process to sell The Ritz hotel and are considering selling the Telegraph Media Group, according to people familiar with their plans, in part to address differing priorities of family members.

The owner of the Daily Mail recently contacted the Barclay family about a potential acquisition of the Telegraph, but the approach was rebuffed, according to two people familiar with the matter.

A takeover by the Daily Mail and General Trust, which is owned by Viscount Rothermere, would create a stable of Conservative-leaning titles spanning the Mail, the Telegraph, and Metro with a combined circulation in the UK approaching that of Rupert Murdoch’s News Corp papers.

Such market power would strengthen the DMGT’s ability to set a common strategy for its newspapers as print sales and advertising revenues steadily decline. But it is likely to run up against a host of regulatory and commercial hurdles, including the price expectations of the Barclay brothers.
